brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to determine whether blockade of the saphenous nerve can
      provide the same degree of analgesia postoperatively for ACLS as a femoral nerve block
      without resulting motor blockade enhancing shortening of hospital stay en functional
      outcome.

clinical_study.brief_title: Analgesic Efficacy of Saphenous Nerve Blockade for Outpatient Knee Anterior Cruciate Ligament Surgery
clinical_study.condition: Postoperative Analgesia for Anterior Cruciate Ligament Surgery of the Knee

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  age 18-65 years

          -  ASA status I - III

          -  rupture of the anterior cruciate ligament.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  contraindication for regional anesthesia

          -  allergy against local anesthetics

          -  BMI > 35

          -  pre-existing diagnosed neuropathy of the operated leg

          -  ingestion of strong opioids

          -  pregnancy or breastfeeding status

          -  History of significant cardiovascular disease (MI, CVA, peripheral vascular disease)

clinical_study.official_title: Analgesic Efficacy of Saphenous Nerve Blockade for Outpatient Knee Anterior Cruciate Ligament Surgery

authority: Netherlands: The Central Committee on Research Involving Human Subjects (CCMO)
Netherlands: Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport

primary_outcome.measure: Readiness to discharge from day-care center in hours according to Post-Anesthetic Discharge Scoring System (PADSS).[

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to rescue analgesic and post operative opioid consumption

clinical_study.source: Academisch Medisch Centrum - Universiteit van Amsterdam (AMC-UvA)
